Corn, also known as maize (scientific name: Zea mays), is a cereal grain and one of the most widely grown and important crops in the world. It is a staple food in many countries and has a wide range of uses. Corn is believed to have originated in the Americas and has been cultivated for thousands of years.

Corn is a versatile and important crop that has been cultivated and consumed by people for centuries. It plays a significant role in agriculture, food production, and various industries around the world.

Scientists believe people living in central Mexico developed corn at least 7000 years ago. It was started from a wild grass called teosinte.

Northern corn leaf blight (NCLB) is a plant disease that affects corn crops, causing significant damage to the plants and leading to reduced yields and economic losses for farmers; it can be caused by various pathogens, including fungi and bacteria.

Northern Corn Leaf Blight (NCLB) is a plant ailment that impacts corn crops, resulting in substantial harm to the plants and resulting in diminished harvests and financial setbacks for farmers. It can be instigated by a range of pathogens, encompassing fungi and bacteria.

Northern corn leaf blight (NCLB) is caused by the fungus Setosphaeria turcica. Symptoms usually appear first on the lower leaves. Leaf lesions are long (1 to 6 inches) and elliptical, gray-green at first but then turn pale gray or tan.
Setosphaeria turcica is a fungal pathogen known for causing Northern corn leaf blight in maize (corn) plants.

This disease can lead to significant damage to corn crops, resulting in reduced yields and economic losses for farmers. The fungus primarily affects the leaves of the corn plants and can cause characteristic elongated lesions with dark borders.

patterns: symptoms  of blight on corn leaf
what are the symptoms of blight?
symptoms of blight on corn leaf
responses: The symptoms of blight in corn leaves, particularly Northern corn leaf blight caused by the fungus Setosphaeria turcica, manifest as elongated lesions with dark, tan, or grayish centers and a characteristic dark border, running parallel to the veins of the corn leaf. These lesions can extensively blight the leaves, reducing photosynthesis and overall plant health, potentially leading to significant reductions in corn yields and economic losses for farmers. In advanced stages, spore-bearing structures (pycnidia) may develop within the lesions. The disease can also affect other parts of the corn plant, including tassels and husks, and severe infestations can result in stunted growth and premature plant death. Monitoring and implementing management strategies, such as using resistant corn varieties and fungicides, are crucial for mitigating its impact on corn crops.

patterns: how to  management and control of blight in corn leaf?
responses: Treating northern corn leaf blight involves using fungicides. For most home gardeners this step isn't needed, but if you have a bad infection, you may want to try this chemical treatment. The infection usually begins around the time of silking, and this is when the fungicide should be applied. Delaro® 325 SC Fungicide and Delaro® Complete Fungicide are both labeled for the control of NCLB. The labels state that either product can be sprayed when the disease first appears. With the use of Delaro® 325 SC Fungicide, if disease development persists a second application can be made at a 7- to 14-day interval.

A general recommendation for corn foliar diseases caused by fungal pathogens is to consider a fungicide application if a disease is present on the third leaf below the ear leaf or higher on 50% of the plants at tasseling and if the product is susceptible to the disease. Both Delaro® 325 SC Fungicide and Delaro® Complete Fungicide are approved for managing NCLB (Northern Corn Leaf Blight). According to their labels, either of these products can be applied as soon as the disease becomes apparent. In the case of Delaro® 325 SC Fungicide, if the disease continues to progress, a second application can be administered with a 7- to 14-day gap.

Azoxystrobin is a fungicide belonging to the strobilurin class. It is widely used in agriculture to control various fungal diseases in crops.
Azoxystrobin is commonly used to control diseases caused by fungi, including rusts, leaf spots, and other foliar diseases.
Azoxystrobin works by inhibiting the mitochondrial respiration in fungi, disrupting the energy production process and ultimately leading to the death of the fungal cells.
The main uses of azoxystrobin include its application on crops such as corn, soybeans, wheat, and others to protect them from fungal infections and improve overall crop yield.

The mode of action of propiconazole involves inhibiting the biosynthesis of ergosterol in fungal cell membranes, disrupting their integrity and function.
